item.description:
NEW HAMPSHIRE SERIES:
Mt. Waumbek, Mt. Weeks and South Weeks ... Three NE Hundred Highest Peaks!

EVENT ORGANIZER: Julie Moran. Please contact me here with your thoughts and ideas about this trip: jmmoran {{AT}} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 518-281-5882 (please, no phone calls prior to the event). Be sure to review all information below prior to your attendance, and also be sure to read our GUIDELINES. FINISH YOUR NE HUNDRED HIGHEST 48 4,000 LIST WITH US!


ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS

Difficulty: 12.0 miles, about 3,654' of vertical climb; at a 1.5 mile / hour pace this is about an eight-hour hike.

Meetup, Car Spot: 7 a.m.

Trailhead Start Time : 8 a.m.

CLICK HERE: Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the CAR SPOT at the end of York Pond Road, north of Berlin, NH (ALL HIKERS GO HERE FIRST); then to the HIKE START at the Starr King Trailhead at the end of a short unnamed forest road just opposite the end of Route 115A, off of U.S. 2, Jefferson, NH).


This hike invariably passes over Mt. Waumbek's sister peak, Mt. Starr King, which has a distinctive summit clearing featuring a standing fireplace from an old inn, and a resident pair of grey jays.



TRIP SUMMARY / UPDATES (11/25/2010 6:15 p.m.): This thru-hike (traverse) along the Kilkenny Ridge is a cross-posted event with Hiking Mates CHALLENGE, New England Hiking Meetup and the 4 Seasons Hiking Group. If the group decides, we can skip Waumbek and just do a RT hike to Mt. Weeks and South Weeks; this hike is about two miles shorter. These hikes are weather dependent ... please stay close to the website for updates. NOTE: This was an event rescheduled from November 26th.

The plan includes travel along the Starr King Trail, named for the 19th Century notable Reverend The plan Starr King which many gentry visited in the late 1800's. It is also a segment of the Cohos Trail which runs the length of Coos County and is infrequent marked with Cohos Trail signs.


ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items, sun screen; trekking poles may be helpful for this hike. NOTE: Snow shoes, poles and friction devices for boots, such as micro-spikes, "Yak-Traks" and / or crampons, are ESSENTIAL as added gear should wet rock surfaces freeze.

CLICK HERE FOR CURRENT SNOW DEPTH INFORMATION FOR NEW HAMPSHIRE.

Be sure to have a method for backpack attachment for these items; be sure to try out your gear before you start out for your first winter trip. TEST YOUR LIGHTS.




RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:

CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP PLANNER OF THE HIKE ROUTE -- PRINT AND TAKE A COPY WITH YOU (be sure to click on the tab link labeled "Mt. Waumbek-Mt. Weeks Thru-Hike" at bottom).


AREA OVERVIEW -- TRAIL DESCRIPTIONS AND TRIP REPORTS
Link, Area Overview, Peakbagging the 4000 Footer Mountains of New England

MT. WAUMBEK
Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, Hike the Whites
Link, Peakbagger
Link, LocalHikes
Link, Wikipedia

MT. WEEKS
Link, Peakbagger
Link, Wikipedia

SOUTH WEEKS
Link, Peakbagger
Link, Wikipedia


Link, Trail Description - Starr King Trail

Link, Up-To-Date Trail Conditions


This is Mt. Weeks, a summer view as seen from Kilkenny Ridge, with the Presidential Range in the background.



NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN FOR UPDATES TO ANY HIKING MATES CHALLENGE EVENT. BY ATTENDING YOU'VE AGREED THAT YOU'VE READ INFORMATION PRESENTED HERE AND AT OUR GUIDELINES -- CLICK THE "ABOUT" LINK AT LEFT.

See you there! Julie and Mike.
item.how_to_find_us: Look for the Green Honda Element ...
